posts.name: Abigail Gonzalez
posts.cooked: I’ve recently become the new software lead, primarily because all our programmers Graduated. While I’m feeling a bit nervous about leading, I’d love to hear everyone’s ideas for the off-season to help us grow our skills quickly. This is my first time on Chief Delphi—sorry if I made any mistakes!

posts.name: Ben Kallhoff
posts.cooked: Similar situation here, I'm trying to focus on teaching younger team members to avoid this situation in the future.

Here’s a cleaned-up version of your text:

"We were planning to tackle things we don't fully understand yet. One significant aspect of our team is improving simulation and command-based programming, as we've been using timed robots for a while and want to adopt newer technologies. We'll also be offering training in programming to those interested, and there's already a group eager to learn. My advice is to focus on something valuable for next year and support others' learning to prepare for future challenges."

As a software team, this offseason, we worked on robot and vision simulations with the goal of completing the test chassis set by the mechanics. Our project aimed to create a one-button solution for aligning all reefs, which is available for further exploration at [link]. The corresponding code is accessible at [GitHub link]. If you have any questions, feel free to reach out without hesitation.

link_counts.title: GitHub - Giro-FRC/AdvantageKitSwerve: AdvantageKitSwerve in off season

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked:
Knowing where and how to find solutions online for software problems.

Where is wpilib docs and what’s in it.

Where are the APIs located and how to navigate them.

Finding out what tools are available to you and how they are used.

Language-specific basics such as C++, Java, Python, and Kotlin.

Command-based programming basics, particularly factory methods.

Understanding PID control and best practices for tuning PID gains.

All of this information can be found on WPILib or product-specific documentation.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: One thing that's under-valued and always worth time investment is fault detection! There's a WPILib pull request for a working resistance detection algorithm that's been stagnant for years due to a lack of real-world testing.

link_counts.title: [wpilib] Add class to calculate robot resistance by calcmogul · Pull Request #5500 · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
This depends heavily on where your team is at. I’ll share my thoughts on what I believe your team should focus on this offseason:

Vision is becoming increasingly important in FIRST Robotics Competition. Focus on building a chassis bot with cameras. While not a perfect fit for competition robots, this setup is ideal for improving vision-related coding. Key goals include finding the right camera configuration, experimenting with resolution settings, identifying suitable coprocessors, and achieving precise pose estimations.

Camera placement must adapt to AprilTag positions on the field, so avoid fixing camera setups before the season starts. Prioritize filtering and processing vision data to prevent discarding good information or accepting bad data. Consider implementing advanced filtering techniques and strive to make your team members highly familiar with how your vision systems operate.

Autonomous driving has room for improvement. Last year, our team struggled with rapid alignment and navigation due to a lack of strong drivetrain control. Focus on refining autoalignment and path-following algorithms this offseason.

Exploring different control systems across mechanisms could benefit your team, even if they don’t use them this year. Revisit past designs, especially the pivot subsystem from previous years. Push forward with state-space control for critical components and ensure proficiency in implementing PID controllers.

Reviewing old code and learning from past mistakes is valuable. Avoid writing unfuture-proof code, as this caused delays last year. Consider adopting best practices, such as adhering to design patterns, and document your code for easier modifications. Modularity and simplicity in coding are essential for long-term maintainability.

Log systems like Advantage Scope offer potential benefits for monitoring and debugging. Focus on setting up effective logging to aid in troubleshooting and analysis.

Engage with simulations to catch bugs early. Read documentation thoroughly, as doing so has been instrumental in saving time and preventing headaches.

Educating new team members is crucial. Be prepared to mentor anyone joining your team, ensuring they can handle responsibilities effectively. Maintain a culture of continuous learning and improvement.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: Typically, vision and logging are important investments in your future. Reprogramming a robot, whether this year's or last year's, etc., is essential. Ensure it's a SwerveBot; it simplifies handling a SwerveBase. Focus on learning about wrist codes, arm codes, elevator systems, various sensors, or upgrading your automation skills. Additionally, exploring LEDs is a fantastic project—they offer both aesthetic value and practical experience in wiring, making them an enjoyable side endeavor.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: Yep. The original version was Previewed in April 2022… it worked in sim, so it just needs someone with an actual robot to test it IRL. I assume lack of user interest is why it’s been ignored for 3 years, so I wouldn’t expect anyone to use it even if we do merge it.

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked: Look over old code. Also, look over other’s code! Also, did you see something somebody else was doing that made you wonder how do they do this? Also, I’ve personally found looking at other’s styling or coding standards has been a good way to find what works best for me.

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: We had designed a public auto alignment system. A significant thing we are going to do during the offseason is streamline and consolidate the codebase so we can reuse it every year!

posts.name: Samjackjoetedpaulbill
posts.cooked: Don’t just use LEDs to add a cool factor; ensure they’re visible during gameplay to give feedback to the driver about the robot’s state and tasks being performed—such as acquiring a game piece, detecting an April tag, completing auto alignment, or handling issues like getting stuck. This visibility helps reduce cycle times, diagnose problems quickly, and adapt strategies, like pivoting to another game piece or adjusting to a manual mode if needed.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: That too, it’s definitely a good thing to get something under your belt and be ready to use it in future years. We added LEDs to last year’s robot to get a handle on things, and it looks fantastic.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
To enhance the team’s ability to lead, consider exploring these areas:

1. **Simulation Proficiency**: Aim to master simulations and Mechanism2D models to enable programming without hardware dependencies.

2. **Robot Development**: Build a more complex robot than the previous year's design to deepen understanding of advanced concepts.

3. **Diverse Implementations**: Experiment with various implementations such as full state machines, command-oriented designs, partial state machines, or comprehensive redos of existing code.

4. **Problem Solving**: Address recurring issues like auto handling, state management, path planning, vision systems, and feed-forward mechanisms differently from last year's approach.

5. **Adaptation Learning**: Study and replicate innovative solutions from other teams, simulating and implementing those approaches to foster learning.

6. **Iterative Growth**: Continuously refine skills through iterative efforts, focusing on areas where growth is needed most.

7. **Leadership Readiness**: Engage in leadership development opportunities, such as assisting in workshops, to identify challenges and improve problem-solving abilities effectively.

8. **Collaborative Challenges**: Tackle more intricate topics once team members demonstrate proficiency, enhancing overall technical expertise.

This structured approach balances skill development with practical application, preparing the team for future challenges and fostering growth through collaboration and continuous improvement.
